p: These results of time-of-addition experiments suggested that the antiviral targets might be early events including virus adsorption to the host cell surface and/or virus penetration into host cells. Therefore, to evaluate the effects of RS on the early steps of viral replication, we determined whether it could inhibit IFV adsorption and penetration ( Figure 2). Treatment with 20 and 50 μg/mL RS markedly inhibited IFV adsorption to Madin–Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells ( Figure 2a). Viral penetration was also inhibited by RS in a dose-dependent manner ( Figure 2b), but the effects of RS on viral penetration were lower than its effects on viral adsorption ( Figure 2a,b). These results show that RS targets the IFV adsorption and penetration steps of viral replication in vitro.
